ygData.subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Jeff, ... (Oops. I just noticed that I wrote weak qualitative analysis instead of what I meant, weak quantitative analysis, in the paragraph above.) If

Subject: Re: Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=550414109; y=Cuow8y-PZ1qL1zWt4q5-fX85sofCTYHvxKxXMJ_YXDb8qcluws-0HvBXEEkX9gVl6Xuey4-K5yH_kpI
X-Yahoo-Profile: rhiever489

Hey Jeff,

> > What if we show qualitative results of multiple evolutionary=
 runs? At that point, if the phenomenon is truly reproducible across replic=
ate evolutionary runs (w/ different seeds), then we already have a simple q=
ualitative metric: How many replicates reproduced the phenomenon. Of course=
, that is a weak qualitative analysis, but if other measures are lacking, i=
t would still be more informative than saying, "this technique worked once =
(here's a video)."
> 
> That's only true if you can quantitatively measure =
the phenomenon. **If** you can do that, then of course you should report qu=
antitative metrics on it (with p-values, effect sizes, etc.). But my point =
is about results that you can't quantify. Should they be categorically excl=
uded because they resist quantification? 
> 
> For example, are the 3D shap=
es produced by CPPNs on EndlessForms interestingly different from those pro=
duced by L-Systems? Are the images on Picbreeder.com more complex and nuanc=
ed than--or at least, interestingly different from--the images from Dawkins=
' Biomorphs? I think the answer is clearly yes, but any attempt to quantify=
 that would be a wasted exercise: the quantification would be full of probl=
ems, and you'd spend a lot of time forcing a quantitative assessment of som=
ething that is patently obvious to every human being. Why force ourselves t=
o jump through that wasteful, and unhelpful, hoop?

(Oops. I just noticed t=
hat I wrote "weak qualitative analysis" instead of what I meant, "weak quan=
titative analysis," in the paragraph above.)

If we can't quantify what we'=
re trying to show, then what are we really showing? At that point, it's mor=
e of a proof of concept ("hey look! this works in my model!") than a contri=
bution to scientific knowledge. Proofs of concept are great to see so peopl=
e know we have it working, and are best presented as a poster or late-break=
ing abstract. A proof of concept by itself probably won't be enough content=
 to properly fill a full-length paper.

In the example you bring up, what d=
oes the statement, "the 3D shapes produced by CPPNs on EndlessForms [are] i=
nterestingly different from those produced by L-Systems," actually tell us?=
 I agree that such a statement would be difficult to quantify because it is=
 a hollow statement (which touches on my section about hypothesis construct=
ion). What about the shapes makes them interestingly different? What is it =
about the underlying architecture that made the shapes interestingly differ=
ent? Answering those questions would lead to a quantitative measure out of =
necessity.

In short, if a statement can't be quantified, then it probably =
hasn't been refined enough.

Cheers,
Randy
